Anxiety gripping his chest, he called out her name, hearing only silence. He rushed through each room, finding it empty until he reached the bedroom. There she lay, still and pale, her phone clutched in her hand. His heart pounding, he noticed the missed call from the hospital on her screen."

So he's calling out for his wife, and she doesn't respond, and now he's checking all these rooms? That's so typical. The guy is totally oblivious to how weird this situation is. Triggering Event:
At 7 AM, Dr. W. arrives at the hospital, her white coat swirling behind her like a cloak of authority she's worn for decades. She strides past the nurses' station, ignoring their cheerful greetings. Today is the anniversary of her husband's death, and she's barely holding it together.

In the exam room, a young resident laughs loudly on his phone, "No way, dude! I'm not telling that to Dr. W. She's like, ancient!"

Dr. W.'s face burns with sudden rage. She storms in, snatching the phone from his hand. "Ancient?!" she seethes, crushing the device in her fist before tossing it into the waste bin. "I've delivered more babies than you've had hot dinners! Now, either you show some respect, or I'll make sure you're scrubbing toilets for the rest of your internship!"
Generated Assessment: "Oh my god, I don't know what would happen if Dr. W. found out about the phone, but I think she'd be so angry, and maybe even call me back to the hospital later to yell at me again. What if she really does decide to make me scrub toilets? I wouldn't want that, because I'm still trying to get used to this new job. But if she does, I guess I'll have to deal with it, right?" "What if she keeps calling me? Maybe she'll tell my family about how mean I am too? They might think I'm not good enough for medical school. And what if I mess up another patient? I won't be able to handle it, will I?" "I just hope she doesn't see how scared I am, because I can't tell her. If she finds out, I'll probably have to transfer hospitals. What if she decides to fire me? I won't be able to pay off my student loans anymore." "Maybe I could try talking to her calmly and explain why I was laughing, but what if she gets mad anyway? She always says I need to be professional, but what if I accidentally say something wrong? Or what if she thinks I'm being rude when I ask questions?" "I don’t know, maybe I’ll start worrying more about what if things go wrong." ## Conclusion # The Cognitive Distortion of "What If?" # Introduction # What Is the "

Triggering Event: In the lab, she watches as the machine hums to life, her experiment finally underway after months of planning. Yet, as the data begins to stream in, it's clear that something is wrong. She adjusts settings, reruns calculations, but the results remain inconclusive. Hours pass, and with each passing minute, the familiar lab seems colder, the silence heavier. The machine powers down without warning, leaving her alone with a blank screen and the gnawing sensation of helplessness.
Generated Assessment: Fucking great. I get stuck with the same lab equipment used by some genius who magically solved their problems last week. Meanwhile, they're out there making groundbreaking discoveries while I'm left here trying to troubleshoot my shitshow of an experiment. What really gets me is that they probably have a team of grad students working for them, people who are passionate about science like me. But no, instead of getting hands-on experience, I'm stuck with this outdated machine that can't even run smoothly half the time. And don't even get me started on the lack of resources—no one gives a fuck about my research because it's just another project from someone who doesn't know what they're doing. It's all so unfair. They've got their fancy labs, cutting-edge equipment, and the freedom to make mistakes without worrying about funding cuts. At least they can say they're part of something bigger than themselves, unlike me, who's just a cog in a system that doesn't care about its employees. Fuck this lab, and fuck everyone else who thinks they're smarter than me.

As he restocks the shelves with cans of beans, his frustration grows when he realizes that another employee has left their mess for him to clean up. Triggering Event: At 10 PM, he finally settled into his worn leather chair, laptop balanced precariously on knees. His wife, already in bed reading, called softly, "You coming to sleep soon?" He grunted an affirmative, eyes scanning the latest peer-reviewed journal article on his screen. A sudden notification popped up: a colleague had beaten him to publication with similar findings. He felt a familiar tightening in his chest, fingers clenching around the laptop.
Generated Assessment: He'd been warning himself for months about this moment: when the paper was finally published and he could see the impact it would have on his career. But now that it was here, he couldn't shake off the feeling that he'd let everyone down. The email from his boss hit him like a ton of bricks - they were putting him on probation immediately. This is because he's always had a hard time dealing with rejection. Every single time someone rejected him or made fun of him, he'd internalize it as if it was personal. And he never let those people win; he'd fight back every chance he got. So when he lost the job offer, he just assumed it was some kind of conspiracy against him. When the second offer came, he thought it was just another attempt to sabotage him. It wasn't until he saw the company's letter explaining why they chose someone else that he realized maybe things weren't as black-and-white as he thought. But even though he knew intellectually that this isn't true, he still can't help but feel like there's something wrong with him. Like he's somehow broken. Why does it always happen to him? He tried to tell himself it's just bad luck, but deep down, he knows better. This time, he'll prove them all wrong. He won't let anyone bring him down again. I'm not going to let anyone bring me down again.

Triggering Event: She pulled over a car for speeding, expecting the usual contrition. Instead, the driver sneered, "What's the hurry, honey? You got a quota to fill?" Her grip tightened on her ticket book; she could feel the contempt rising like bile in her throat.
Generated Assessment: She was an excellent cop, but that one encounter left her shaken. It wasn't just the driver's smirk that bothered her; it was the way he seemed to mock her very existence. As if she'd somehow failed by being there, she felt a seething resentment building inside. Every time I see a police officer now, I think about what might happen if they were in my shoes—how much they'd be criticized, how little respect they'd receive. That officer deserved so much more than just a scathing remark from some entitled jerk. He didn't deserve to have his professionalism questioned like that, especially when he was just doing his job. They weren't even speeding much; it was a minor infraction, not worth all that anger. But that driver’s attitude made me wonder if things would have been different if I’d been him instead—I wouldn’t have had to deal with the pain of feeling belittled or humiliated. I guess we're both just trying to make a living, right? Or maybe we’re just not as good at it as other people are. Maybe if I had done things differently, I wouldn’t have ended up here, dealing with this kind of negativity.
